General course objectives:
General course objectives
This three-week intensive course dives deep into biomedical sensor technology, focusing on the design, development, and prototyping of flexible and wearable sensors. Students will gain hands-on experience with a range of sensor technologies, including resistive, capacitive, inductive, piezoelectric, electrochemical, and temperature sensors. The course is structured to allow students to progress from understanding basic sensor principles to designing and analyzing sophisticated sensor prototypes, culminating in a final project where these prototypes are demonstrated.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
discuss the operational principles and applications of various sensor technologies, including resistive, capacitive, inductive, piezoelectric, and electrochemical sensors.
select appropriate, biocompatible materials for the development of flexible and wearable sensors.
design sensor prototypes, from conceptual sketches to detailed schematics.
employ advanced prototyping techniques for sensor fabrication, with a focus on flexibility and wearability.
analyze sensor functionality through both qualitative and quantitative testing methods.
integrate diverse sensor technologies into a cohesive prototype to address comprehensive biomedical monitoring needs.
collaborate effectively in teams to enhance problem-solving and innovation in sensor design
present a functional prototype in the final examination, demonstrating integrated learning outcomes, innovative design, and practical applicability in biomedical sensing.
Content:
Basics of sensor technologies and initial prototyping: Introduction to sensor principles; focusing on resistive and capacitive sensors, exploring materials for sensor development; beginning design and prototyping of resistive and capacitive sensors.

Advanced sensor design and prototyping: delving into inductive and piezoelectric sensors; materials and design considerations, and prototyping of temperature and piezoelectric sensors.

Electrochemical sensors and comprehensive prototype development: overview of electrochemical sensors; integration strategies for complex sensing needs, design, and prototyping of electrochemical and advanced flexible temperature sensors, integrating sensor technologies into a multifunctional prototype.
